newsitem.title: USA: URS to buy Woodward-Clyde for $100 mln.
newsitem.headline: URS to buy Woodward-Clyde for $100 mln.

text.p: URS Corp has signed a definitive agreement to buy privately owned Woodward-Clyde Group Inc for $100 million in stock and cash, the two engineering companies said Tuesday.
Terms of the deal call for Denver-based Woodward-Clyde stockholders to receive $65 million of URS common stock plus $35 million cash, they said.
The acquisition, scheduled to close in November, is not expected to have a material impact on URS fiscal 1998 earnings, they said.
The companies said the proposed combination will create the fifth largest U.S. engineering firm, with revenues of $800 million and more than 6,000 employees.
The transaction is subject to the approval by stockholders of both companies as well as regulatory and other approvals, they said.

"Domestically, the combination balances the geographic distribution of resources to create a dynamic national firm with the ability to provide a full range of services anywhere in the country," URS Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Martin Koffel said.
"Our combined revenue base will escalate URS into one of the leading engineering firms and further enhance our opportunities to win large, high-profile contracts," he said.
The companies said it is expected that Woodward-Clyde President and Chief Executive Officer Jean-Yves Perez and Chairman Frank Waller will join the URS board.
